The time when AWS announced full restoration of services, indicating the duration and resolution timeline of the outage.

keyTakeAways: The AWS outage was caused by a technical error during a software update to DynamoDB’s API, which led to a DNS failure affecting critical services.
The failure cascaded across 113 AWS services, impacting major platforms including banking apps, social media, gaming services, smart home devices, and media outlets.
The root cause was not a cyberattack or external threat, but human error during a routine update, which is common in complex cloud environments.
The incident underscores the critical dependence of modern digital infrastructure on centralized cloud providers like AWS, with global consequences.
AWS restored services and acknowledged the issue, with engineers working in parallel to resolve it quickly and publish a detailed post-mortem.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A major AWS outage on Monday, beginning at 07:11 GMT in Virginia, was triggered by a human error during a software update to DynamoDB’s API, which caused a DNS failure. This cascaded into failures across 113 AWS services, affecting global platforms such as banking apps (Venmo, Coinbase), social media (Snapchat, Pinterest), gaming (Fortnite, Roblox), communication apps (WhatsApp, Zoom), media services (The New York Times, ESPN), and smart home devices (Ring, Alexa). Experts confirmed the incident was not a cyberattack but a result of routine technical error. AWS restored services by 10:11 GMT and acknowledged the issue, with engineers working in parallel to resolve it. The event underscores the immense dependency of modern digital life—ranging from finance to entertainment and personal technology—on centralized cloud infrastructure.
title: What caused Amazon’s AWS outage, and why did so many major apps go offline?
